Comments_List: General knowledge of game theory and its applications

I learned more about ways to look at decision making/a basic rough knowledge of various concepts in game theory. Applications to politics were attached to these concepts at points within the course. This course reading's required summery on Canvas really helped me figure out ways to distill my comments on academic essays and studies that comprised our homework. Psets were done in groups and thus allowed for peer-to-peer knowledge exploration.
Learned evaluative skills and specific historical and current examples of strategic games and other models of political situaitons.
The course gave a general overview of game theory. It was not quantitative at all though, which was a little disappointing as I wanted a more in-depth learning of the subject.

So. 
You don't learn much. This is one of the rare guts where the topic itself is decently interesting, the lectures so disorganized/uninformative, and the readings mediocre that when you put in work, it feels like you make yourself dumber. Key takeaways: politicians, when they solely seek office, are basically bad people. No voting model is perfect.
I learned about different voting systems, game theory, and applying political models to real-life situations.
I learned the basic models of voting and electoral systems in politics, and examples of these in different political systems.
Intro to game theory
Intro game theory.
I developed of basic understanding of game theory applications within politics.
A lot of interesting strategic games and political models that were each tied to some sort of relevant real world problem.

I definitely have a better understanding of formal political models, as well as a little more game theory than I had before. Most of the models are too simple to be useful in real-world contexts, but it's good to at least have somewhere to start.
This course gave me an understanding of basic concepts in game theory and some simple political models of voting, bargaining, and international relations.
This was a super interesting class about how game theory should apply to elections and politics but usually doesn't. Fantastic introduction into the subject of game theory, perfect for all levels.
The course provided me a great, basic intellectual framework which I can use to better evaluate strategic decision making.
Learned a lot about game theory and different models of politics
I have a very basic understanding of different games and their relevance to politics.
A broad overview of game theory models in politics.
Very elementary understanding of game theory in political contexts.
I learned how to evaluate different problems or scenarios using game trees and preferences - and how to apply this to different political scenarios.
basic introduction to game theory and politics

I learned about Nash equilibria, decision making theories, and sequential decision making. I learned basic game theory strategy, as well as some practical applications to real-world problems (especially political ones).
I learned many useful models to describe contemporary political developments.
I developed a better understanding and appreciation rationality in our world, as well as an interesting in when our behavior seems strictly irrational; war costs, incomplete voter preferences, etc.
I learned a bit about Game theory and some stuff about poli-sci but I could have learned more.
You learn a lot of poli sci theories about voting, redistribution, and international relations.
I learned some interesting heuristics for thinking about politics and strategic decision making.
A basic understanding of game theory.
Knowledge about game theory
Very few! I was really excited about this course, but disorganization and lack of vision made it hard to gain anything from the class.
Learned about basic game theory and how its applied in real world politics. Pretty cool stuff.

I learned about rational decision-making and applying game theory to different political contexts. I used basic models such as the Stag Hunt and Prisoner's Dilemma to examine real-world situations resembling these simplified games. In the PSETs, I had the chance to practice the basic set-ups for game theory problems and how to find the subgame perfect equilibrium in game trees.
The subject matter of this course is genuinely fascinating. I gained an appreciation for the nature of decision making, and a window into the complexities of international decision making.

Essentially, the principal task of the class was to reason through scenarios of choice, both political and apolitical, and employ game strategies to that end. Most of the material was fairly intuitive and lent itself well to previous knowledge of microeconomics. Some of the scenarios applied rather confusing equations to their solutions that were never fully explained, though nor were they tested. In taking this class, I became versed in the thought of some of the foremost American political scientists, albeit a limited introduction to very mundane work.
Basics of game theory and their application to political situations
This course allowed me to explore basic concepts relating to game theory such as Nash Equilibrium, matrices, and backward induction.
Classic games of game theory; the fundamentals of game theory; political decision making; political systems and concepts
Learned about strategic games and voting strategies.
The intersection of politics, game theory, and decision-making on the part of politicians, voters, and citizens
This class does not require engagement. The class was not well structured for learning.
I think that some of the exams have very unclear wording that could be worked on.
Strengths of this course are the basics of concepts in game theory. A weakness of this course is the low level of engagement in lectures.

I feel like this class was probably better in its earlier format with less people. Professor Svolik is a great instructor, but there was a portion of the class who did not put in the effort and made the class altogether worse. For some reason, I kind of expected more out of this class in a way. I feel like a lot of class time was spent on these odd formulas with little pay-offs as to how it relates to the big picture.

strengths: good overall, not too technical, engaging
Weaknesses: at times moves a bit slowly, ie class time is used to go over exams and psets that could be used better for other lessons

The course was not organized very well--there were four problem sets but we did not really engage with the course in any other way. Professor Svolik cares a lot about the topics, but they were sometimes very dry and the presentations were not engaging either.

The material was very interesting and Professor Svolik is very passionate about the subject.
However, the course was disorganized. There was a number of lectures that was missed earlier in the term that was never rescheduled even though Professor said it would be. It caused us to rush the entire last week of the course, which was heavily tested on the final.
And during the final, certain exams had missing questions and cut parts from questions, which the TF's were not aware until someone pointed it out during the exam. The students had to wait over an hour to get proper copies of their exams, while they could only squint and try to solve the missing questions through the hastily setup projector. 
The material in the course is very interesting but the course does need some restructuring to be recommended.

Strengths: N/A

Weaknesses:
Jesus Christ. The course was unbelievably disorganized. Professor Svolik seems like a nice guy, but he missed 2x lectures during shopping period (so everyone committed based off of like one class). He said several times we'd make up the lectures but we never did. The problem sets weren't difficult but were worded EXCEEDINGLY confusingly. The midterm was also easy but felt like it was written in the most arcane, obscure form possible. And GOOD GOD. THE FINAL. The final was ~15 questions, ~4 pages. 4 questions had parts of them cut off due to printing errors! And we discovered this half way through the final! And they couldn't get more copies in time! We had to all wait for the TAs to operate some clunky projector and show the parts that were missing on the board so we could answer the questions. Oh, and there was a whole freaking question omitted -- it went straight from 5 to 7, no #6. The lectures just wander. Impossible to pay attention. Class had ~100 kids, 30-50 in lectures.

The professor is an engaging lecturer and clearly finds the topic interesting and exciting. The material is interesting but often surface-level. The class can also sometimes be disorganized and the exams didn't necessarily reward deep knowledge of the material. However, as an introduction to political science for someone outside of the major, it served its purpose and wasn't overwhelming or too jargon-y.

I thought the lectures were interesting and enjoyed the readings and problem sets, but sometimes the coursework could be intuitive and would have been more engaging if made more challenging. I think a discussion section could have made the course more engaging.

Strengths: material is actually pretty interesting if you're into game theory; and it's presented in a digestible manner, not super hard like other game theory courses. Readings can be hard to understand but you just have to get the gist of them. Prof Svolik is great

Weaknesses: not much guidance as to what will be on exams or how to study, but you kind of just figure it out
It went pretty well for the most part.
The course was extremely interesting, but I think that there is room in the term to cover more material.

There was no clear direction about what to expect for exams. There were no practice problems for exams and there was no discussion of format. This class was really interesting, but many of the concepts were superficially covered. Many of the concepts were intuitive and we spent much longer on them than we should have. The lectures were not well-organized. The math was often rushed. There was a lot of reading and reading responses twice a week, but this only counted for 5% of our grade and the readings were not on exams. There is quite a bit of reading so the reading responses should count for a higher percentage of the grade.

Professor Slovik is a passionate lecturer and a really nice guy. Sometimes it felt like he would reiterate the same ideas, even when they were pretty simple. This could get a bit boring at times, but it did help drive home the lectures. I felt like I learned things in this class that I won't just brain-dump after the final. The tests were both super easy, and there were only a few problem sets assigned, so you have to stay on top of your stuff and make sure you don't make silly mistakes.

Strengths: explaining the foundations of political modeling in a reasonably accessible way
Weaknesses: lectures can drag on, and a lot of the math (that we weren't expected to know, but was covered anyway?) went over most of our heads
This class was very easy. I thought the content was interesting, and I would have been happy to cover more content in greater depth. Lectures were sometimes interesting, but sometimes repetitive.
There is a high level of personal expectation to do work, which isn't great for someone who needs deadlines to do readings.
The professor was very insightful but could be improved by more discussions through students
More PSETS, harder exams

This course is a cool concept however it moved very slowly, presented basic models and did not engender considerations beyond what a most students were already familiar with. We could have moved at twice the pace without issue, thereby covering twice the content. More incorporation of the outside readings into class, as began to occur at the end of the course, would have led to more learning.

Quite disorganized - our readings and lectures did not always seem to connect. Our final was a bit of a mess (the professor wasn't there, and a printing mishap meant that everyone in the class had missing pages on their final).
The course itself was fine, but the readings often felt unrelated.

I really liked the real-world applications of the class but often the material was presented in a manner that was watered-down and absent of reasoning. I think that this class would do better as a QR because I'm not sure how game theory (a math-based field) can be taught comprehensively without math.

This class is very easy. If you are looking for a fifth class that will fill a prerequisite for EP&E or political science it is helpful and clearly taught. The readings are often long and irrelevant to the class. It would be useful to cut down the readings or pick ones more relevant to what is discussed in class, or include test questions about the readings because it might encourage more students to be more engaged.
kind of easy class but a bit boring because it is introduction

This course was fun and engaging, but never went particularly in-depth with respect to the material taught. It was mostly a rehashing of the readings in a more game-theoretic framework, which was certainly interesting, but failed to provide any deeper understanding of game theory itself in any meaningful way.

The tests were very poorly worded, which made it incredibly difficult to understand what concept was even being tested.

The lectures were well-delivered, though I do think Prof. Svolik could have been more inventive and dynamic with his presentations, as by the end of the semester it began to feel a little more tedious.
It was the biggest gut I've ever taken.

The syllabus was not laid out week by week, we just kind of moved through topics at our own pace. It was fine, but it made reviewing concepts/missing class difficult bc you never knew what you were gonna learn on a given day really.
Weaknesses: unorganized, not very clear

Organization was a clear weakness. The professor was often a few minutes late for class and would request things from us at the last minute. Slides were impossible to use for review. It wasn't clear what the professor wanted us to get out of the class. Even handing back problem sets took far too long. The final exam was a mis-printed fiasco. The professor didn't ask for participation in class as a component of the grade, but would often wait for long chunks of time in class for someone in the large lecture hall to answer a question that didn't further our learning. Participation wasn't valuable. He spent tremendous time exploring complex models in class that hadn't appeared in readings and would not be tested in homework or the exams, often without explaining clearly why the models were useful in understanding the subject matter. He used Greek letters when other variables would have sufficed and would have been less confusing. What were we supposed to learn?
Milan is awesome, and he really helps to drive this class. Unfortunately not too many people participate. Might be better with more active students.

I generally enjoyed the lectures, especially when Professor Svolik brought in current political dilemmas. However, I sometimes thought Professor Svolik rushed through the game theory involved in the course and did not explain the set-up of the equations or what the end result meant. I actually learned the most game theory during the PSETs and going to office hours. That said, the exams did not demand that much game theory and were structured as true/false statements. Although I would have appreciated some true/false questions, I actually wish the final had more game trees and problems resembling the PSETs. Instead, almost all of the questions were focused on the concepts in the lectures and the readings, which should have made them easy points, except for the wording, which was often unclear and hinged on a single word such as "imply" or "assume." Overall, I thought the workload and material covered in the course was very fair, but I would have preferred more variety and even difficulty in the exam questions and more explanations of the game theory side of the course.

This course is ambitious and has excellent subject matter. In terms of content, it was one of my favourite classes this semester. However, this course has room for improvement in terms of structure. There could be more guidance on what would be on exams before they are given, and lectures could have a larger overall theme. I also wish the difficulty was increased.

The class employs a very reasonable homework schedule. Readings are effective and germane to class material. Problem sets did not consume several evenings worth of effort and tended to reflect past lectures. That being said, there is a fairly cut-and-dry grading scheme that privileges the results of only two exams. If you perform poorly (or even adequately) on the midterm, your grade may very well hang in the balance for the rest of the semester. The course is also taught as a large lecture and attendance was lackluster. Students were not rewarded for submitting reading summary assignments on-time nor were they for showing up to class; perhaps making those two amendments to the grading scheme would make the course more equitable. Also, this IS an EP&E course. Anticipate the crowd it's going to attract. If you take yourself very seriously, take this class.
This course did a very good job introducing game theory and political theory to someone, like myself, with no background in either. That said, it did feel a bit slow and disorganized at times.

Strengths:
- basics of game theory, well explained and very applicable 
- very funny and responsive professor 

Weaknesses:
- a lot of reading for little input
- many more complex formulas and explanations are not in the slides

It seemed to only give a very basic and drawn out approach to game theory, there was not that much content for the course. In the future the professor could move through the topics quicker to address more content.

Strengths: clear, involved, lectures are very organized; outside reading is helpful and interesting; exams are very reflective of the problem sets and lecture material

Weaknesses: no exam review sessions
Problem sets are really straightforward. Not a lot of content, especially the beginning half of the class.
Overall, the course was super easy but did not seem very organized. Also, none of the material was challenging so the lectures were boring at times.

Strength: The professor knows and breaks down the material very well for students during lecture. The material is also very applicable not just to political science but to all of life.

Weakness: The class is large and does not allow for a lot of one-on-one interaction with the professor or TAs.

If you want to take an interesting class and be almost guaranteed a good grade, take this class. If you want to put in work, see yourself improve as a student and learner, and come away with lasting knowledge of the subject, do not take this class.

Yes, I would because the course material is simple and interesting and the class makes it very possible to learn basics. I would caution students though that sometimes the class becomes very math heavy, very quickly, and it can be challenging to recognize which concepts are mathematic tangents, and which are central to the class.

I would recommend it to another student, hopefully with a smaller class size. I feel like this would be much better as a seminar/leminar than a 100-person class. It has interesting points and concepts, but I feel like there was potential for it to be a lot more thought-provoking and interactive, especially in today's political climate. Overall, the professor was really kind and helpful, but I didn't enjoy the class structure or material as much as I was anticipating. I think this could be done with more emphasis on relating lectures to the readings as well as current events.
I have never taken a political science course but I thoroughly enjoyed this course. Professor Svolik is great!

Absolutely. A great 5th class. Very straightforward, only 4 psets (with group work encouraged, each takes an hour), a multiple choice midterm and final, and weekly reading responses. A tiny bit slow at times, but very interesting overall and super applicable to everyday situations.
I would recommend this course to another student. I thought that I learned a lot and that the lectures were all very interesting.

If you need a fifth class, take the class. It is low workload, and as long as you go to lecture, you will do fine.
However, if you want to walk away with any significant knowledge of game theory or political systems, do not expect this course to provide that.

NO! This is a GUT, plain and simple. I'm a fan of guts. But Yale has plenty of guts -- this one isn't even a QR or SC or WR gut, it's just a SO gut. There are guts where you learn something interesting, guts where you breeze by, etc etc. But this gut is 10x more stressful because the sheer and utter disorganization of this course is legitimately something you'd find at a community college. It's ridiculous. There are better guts! Take a better gut!

I would recommend it to someone looking for an engaging, no-frills 5th course. The material applies to a lot of modern political problems and as long as you keep up with the readings and lectures, it's very manageable.
I would recommend this course to a student interested in political science or introductory game theory as an introduction to basic voting models.

Definitely would recommend this course
Material is interesting but not too hard
Sure. Nothing too offensive.
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student.
I would recommend this course to someone who needs to fulfill a game theory requirement. The concepts are interesting but they were not covered in depth.

I would recommend this class to anyone who doesn't have a good background in game theory or experience with political models. If they do, then this class will be very easy. For me, it was a very interesting but relaxed class
Probably. It's not as much of a gut as people say (the psets can genuinely be a little tricky), but worth taking, especially if you're interested in the quantitative side of political science.

This class is an incredibly easy social science gut. There are only four psets that take about 30 minutes each, and exams are all multiple choice or true/false. Lectures cover the same content as the readings, so if you go to lecture (or read someone else's notes), doing the readings is pretty unnecessary. The actual content of the course is kind of interesting, so overall, I would recommend it as a fifth (maybe a sixth) class.
I would absolutely recommend this course - interesting, topical, easy, and at the very, very least, gives you something interesting to talk to your political relatives about at Christmas.

Absolutely. This course provides a great introduction to game theory and strategic decision making, with little math involved. If you are unfamiliar with the concepts and want to learn more about the social sciences, I definitely recommend taking the course. A lot of the conclusions seem like "common sense," but are nonetheless extremely interesting. Readings are pretty light, and the problem sets and exams not especially difficult. Surprisingly, this turned out to be what I consider one of the most important classes I've taken at Yale for developing the perspective with which I view the world.

This is one of those guts that you wish you hadn't taken, despite how easy it was. The course focused on basic, basic game theory (think Prisoner's Dilemma for weeks on end) and other intuitively simple concepts (think expected payoff) up until literally the last lecture, during with Professor Svolik decided to toss in theorems/paradoxes that were actually novel and interesting. So it wasn't that the theme was a dud, just the way that it was taught. Only take it if you're desperate for an A, and even then, I advise you not to waste your time going to class. I assure you that by week 3, half of the class will be skipping as well.
Yes, good introduction into game theory and politics
Take this class if you want to learn game theory
You have to take it for EPE, but given that you can only take 36 classes during your time at Yale it is better not to waste one selection on a class that can be replicated by an hour on Wikipedia.
Yes, its a good way to dip your toe into game theory.
If you need it as a requirement, it is the easiest way to satisfy game theory.
I would recommend this course to a student looking to fill a prerequisite or interested in logic as it relates to politics.
yes if you don;t know a lot about politics and you want light and easy class

I would recommend this course as a fifth class. There were only a few Problem Sets and the required readings are not dense or difficult. The lectures are fun and interesting to contemplate. However, if you're looking for a deep introduction to Game Theory and strategy, this is not the class for you. It is intended to be as non-mathy as possible, so this makes it a great class for humanities kids, but even still it lacks some of the depth you might find elsewhere.
Definitely take this if you need a Poly Sci Gut. The workload is super light, the material is objectively intriguing, and the grading is extremely lenient.

Yes, provided they have some interesting in Game Theory and Politics.  The math wasnt extremely difficult, but it helped to have a basic understanding of strategic games and an interest in current events.
If you want to take a gut lol.

Its a good fifth class. I rarely went because lecture was boring and the concepts are easy to grasp if you go to a few lectures. Definitely not the most exciting/mind blowing class in the world though, especially because the theories we learn arent super applicable to the real world/complex.
Yes, because it enhances your knowledge on game theory
No. The course needs clear restructuring. It started off promising, but never fulfilled any particular vision for a set of things we were to learn.

I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in politics and the basics of game theory. I also thought the workload was more than manageable and the PSETS were actually enjoyable. The lectures could get a bit long, especially with the dim lights of Sudler Hall, but the material was usually engaging especially for those interested in voting, cycles of government, and representation.
I would recommend in terms of the assigned readings. The course also has a nice and compassionate instructor.
Great fifth class! The workload is very low but the topics are still really interesting!

Maybe. If you're exploring the potential of pursuing a degree in EP&E or are looking to satisfy a political theory requirement, the class is a good introduction to the major and is very manageable. If you have any reason NOT to take the class, or can satisfy a credit elsewhere, DO THAT. The lecture is long and assuredly boring. Many students struggle to keep their eyes open in the warm darkness of Sudler Hall (and right after lunch, to boot). The material is very dry and very intuitive. Some readings will have you wondering "why did someone need to write this out? Like, doesn't everyone know this already?" Some lectures will have you wondering what the hell just happened. The course tends to be well-organized, though tests are worded notoriously poorly and can prove rather confusing. Problem sets sometimes consider scenarios we hadn't covered in class. In sum, I didn't particularly enjoy my time in this course and wish I hadn't taken it.
It's definitely a good course to take if you want to gain a basic understanding of political theory and reduce your workload.
This is a wonderful entry to game theory with light applications in politics. Funny, interesting, and strengthening the basic understanding of political interactions worldwide!
Yes take this course; great especially for non-Econ majors to learn about game theory
Definitely a gut, truly didn't learn much. Pretty chill class overall. Lectures are super slow. Pretty easy to catch up on content via slides without going to class.

If you're looking to fulfill a game theory requirement, don't waste your time with anything else. This class is a no brainer workload wise, and is actually way more interesting because of the political applications. Seriously, save yourself some stress and take this class.
I would recommend this course if you are looking for a very basic class or you want an easy A. I do not regret taking the class at all.
Yes, I would. This class develops a very applicable foundation to other political science classes as well as history and economics.
